# CreateMapping

**Instance Method**

Maps the contents of the memory block to the address space of the current process.

## Declaration

```swift
kern_return_t CreateMapping(uint64_t options, uint64_t address, uint64_t offset, uint64_t length, uint64_t alignment, IOMemoryMap * * map);
```

## Parameters

- **options**: The options to use when mapping the memory into this process. For a list of possible values, see [doc://com.apple.driverkit/documentation/DriverKit/3325558-memory_map_options].
- **address**: The address in the current process’ memory space at which to place the memory block. Specify a value for this parameter only if you also specified the [doc://com.apple.driverkit/documentation/DriverKit/kIOMemoryMapFixedAddress] option; otherwise, specify `0`.
- **offset**: The offset into the buffer to use as the first byte. Specify a value for this parameter only if you want to map from somewhere other than the first byte of the buffer; otherwise, specify `0`.
- **length**: The number of bytes accessible to the memory mapping. Specify `0` to map the entire buffer into memory, or specify a value that is less than the current length of the buffer.
- **alignment**: The byte alignment to use when mapping the memory into your process. Specify only 0 for this parameter.
- **map**: A variable in which to store the newly created [doc://com.apple.driverkit/documentation/DriverKit/IOMemoryMap] object. The returned object has a retain count of 1. You are responsible for releasing this object when you are finished with it.

## Return Value

[doc://com.apple.driverkit/documentation/DriverKit/kIOReturnSuccess] on success, or another value if an error occurs. See [doc://com.apple.driverkit/documentation/DriverKit/error-codes].

## Discussion

Use this method to map a memory buffer created by another process into the address space of the current process.

## Mapping to the Caller’s Address Space

- **Memory Map Options**: Options that describe how to configure a memory-mapped buffer.
